texts.en: Neang H., 45, sells vegetables at a local food market, making $5 per day, while her husband, Sou Veng, works as a fisherman. They live in Kampong Chhnang province and Sou Veng's salary of $2.5 per day helps them to support five children and Neang H.'s elderly father who lives with them. Neang H. has asked for a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike for her son. He would like to start operating his own motortaxi service and the family believes this diversification of income can greatly benefit the family. In the future, Neang H. plans to purchase a large stand in the market to sell various kinds of vegetables and other grocery products.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike for her son

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Ruqaiya

texts.en:
Ruqaiya baji is the wife of B. M. and lives in an area of city Lahore named Ismail Nagar, Pakistan. She has been living in this area for the last 12 years. She is the mother of four children: three daughters and one son. Her two daughters are married. Her younger daughter is in 8th standard. Her son is in the 7th standard (grade).

Her husband is a carpenter by profession. He makes wooden material (kitchen cabinets and doors) on order. Ruqaiya baji has a business of making coverlets. She makes coverlets and sells them in the market and earns a profit. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy wood for her husband so that he is able to complete the orders of his customers.

loans.use: To buy woods to make kitchen cabinets and doors

loans.name: Sesame Rice Crackers, Livestock, Rice Noodles, Clothes, Wholesale Retail Group

texts.vi:
chị Vũ thị Tính năm nay 36 tuổi Ms 13050020, vợ chồng chị có 2 con, cả 2 con chị còn nhỏ và đang đi học. Hàng ngày chị và chồng làm nghề tráng bánh đa để bán và chăn nuôi thêm tại nhà. Chị đã vay vốn qua một C. kỳ và hoàn trả vốn rất tốt, C. kỳ này chị lại tiếp tục đăng ký vay ở mức 4.256.000 VND để mua gạo tráng bánh. Trong nhóm chị có các thành viên sau :

  • chị N. thị Chung Ms 13050007 vay mức 4.704.000 VND để chăn nuôi và tráng bánh phở
  • chị Đặng thị Dinh Ms 13050008 vay mức 3.360.000 VND mua vải may quần áo bán
  • chị C. thị Bắc Ms 13050009 vay mức 3.808.000 VND để thêm vốn đi chợ
  • chị Nguyễn thị Liệu Ms 13050010 vay mức 4.704.000 VND vay vốn trồng trọt, chăn nuôi .
texts.en:
Mrs. Tinh Thi V. is 36 years old. She and her husband have two small children, both of whom are going to school. Each day she and her husband make sesame rice crackers to sell and also raise livestock to supplement their income. She has already completed one funding round and has repaid the loan with good conduct. In this round of funding she is registering again for a loan, in the amount of 4,256,000 VND to buy more rice to make the crackers. Her group also includes the following participants:

  • Mrs. Chung Thi Nghiem, requesting 4,704,000 VND to raise livestock and make rice noodles.
  • Mrs. Dinh Thi Dang, requesting 3,360,000 VND to buy fabric for making clothes to sell.
  • Mrs. Bac Thi C., requesting 3,808,000 VND to use as capital for wholesale retail business.
  • Mrs. Lieu Thi Nguyen, requesting 4,704,000 VND to grow plants to sell, and to raise livestock.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more rice, fabric, buy wholesale goods

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en:
Parveen baji is the wife of R. M. A. and lives in an area of Lahore named Ismail Nagar, Pakistan. She has been living in this area for the last 12 years. She is the mother of five children: two girls and three boys. Her daughters and a son are married. The next eldest son is doing B.com (finance) and the younger son works in a factory as a accountant. 

Parveen baji's husband strived very hard throughout his life because he wants to give his children a better education along with good future. He did several jobs, selling shopping bags on roads, selling clothes on a cart with a loud voice. By the grace of God and through his struggle, God rewarded him to make him the owner of a readymade garment shop. Parveen baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She successfully repaid her four loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more readymade garments to resell.

loans.use: To buy more readymade garments to resell

loans.name: Shahnaz

texts.en:
Shahnaz baji is the wife of M. A. and lives in an area of Lahore named Ismail Nagar, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the last 9 years. She is the mother of four boys. Her elder son couldn't get an education because of his problems paying attention in his studies. The next eldest to him is in the 9th standard. The younger to him is in the 8th standard. Her younger son is in the 5th standard. 

Shahnaz baji's husband makes stoves, which are used to cook food. He has been in this profession since his childhood. Shahnaz baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She successfully repaid her four loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy material (tools, steel) to make more stoves.

loans.use: To buy material to make stoves

loans.name: San

texts.en:
Mr. San S. is a villager in Khsom Village in Kandal Province. His wife, Mrs. Sok Nith, pictured on the left of the photograph, is a gardener in the USA embassy in Phnom Penh city, Cambodia. San is 22 years old, and he is the father of a 1-year-old child, who is thus too young to work or study.

San is a motorbike taxi driver who would like to generate greater income to support his family. Currently, San is experiencing problems with his business because his motorbike is rather old, so he necessarily spends a lot of money on gas/petroleum. As a result, he is requesting a loan in order to purchase another motorbike, which would allow him to save more money for the benefit of his family.

loans.use: To save fuel costs by purchasing another motorbike.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Pan

texts.en: Mrs. Pan S. lives in Khsom Village in Kandal Province, where she owns a small grocery store in the local market. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. She decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery products for her inventory in order to meet her consumers' demands. Her husband, Mr. Yoem Bunly, is a fortune teller, which typically generates an income of around $4 a day. Mrs. Pan S. is 38 years old and the mother of one child who is five years old.

loans.use: To buy more grocery goods for her customers

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Saom

texts.en: Saom C., 51, is married and she lives with four of her six children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Since 2000, she has had a business selling "Nom Banchok" rice noodles. They are one of the favorite foods of Cambodian people. Rice noodles are served with many kinds of vegetables such as: mint, banana blossoms, string beans, English cucumber, mung bean sprouts and other vegetables. They are also used in two types of soup; green and red soup. Green soup is cooked with boneless fish and it is called in "Nom Banchok Samlah Khmer". Red soup can be cooked with pork or chicken and is called "Nom Banchok Namya". On average, she makes $1 of profit per day and she is helped by her child who works as a garment worker as well. Mrs. Saom would like to loan from Kiva to build a cage to raise pigs for extra profit for the family.

loans.use: To build a cage to raise pigs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Văn Hai's Group

texts.vi:
anh Nguyễn văn Hải Ms 13050033 năm nay anh 31 tuổi, hiện nay gia đình anh có 2 con nhỏ và đang đi học. Vợ anh ở nhà chăn nuôi, còn anh mở cửa hàng bán phân đạm và thuốc trừ sâu, nên mức thu nhập của gia đình anh cũng khá ổn định từ 180.000 VND đến 200.000 VND / ngày. Anh rất thích tham gia vay vốn của Bình Minh cdc, vì vay hình thức này giúp vợ chồng anh tích luỹ được tiền cho tương lai. Đồng thời vợ chồng anh lại được trả dần, anh đăng ký vay 3.186.000 VND để đầu tư vào cửa hàng phân đạm của gia đình. Trong nhóm anh có các thành viên sau :

  • chị Đào thị Hà Ms 13050032 vay mức 3.186.000 VND để tráng bánh đa nem
  • chị Nguyễn thị Nhàn Ms 13050034 vay mức 2.006.000 VND để bán hàng tại nhà
  • anh Tô văn Hồng Ms 13050035 vay mức 3.186.000 VND để kinh doanh
  • anh Đặng văn Chợ Ms 13050036 vay mức 3.186.000 VND để tráng bánh đa nem
  • anh Trần văn Quế Ms 13050037 vay mức 2.950.000 VND để chăn nuôi .
texts.en:
Mr. Hai Van Nguyen, 31 years old, has two small children who are going to school. His wife stays at home to take care of the children, and he runs a store selling fertilizer and insecticide, so their income is relatively stable at 180,000 VND to 200,000 VND per day. He really enjoys participating in the Binh Minh Fund because this form of funding helps the couple save money for their family's future. At the same time, the fund allows the couple to repay gradually. He is requesting 3,186,000 VND to invest in his fertilizer business. His group also includes the following participants:

  • Mrs. Ha Thi Dao, requesting 3,186,000 VND to make rice wrappers.
  • Mrs. Nhan Thi Nguyen, requesting 2,006,000 VND to do retail sales out of her home.
  • Mr. Hong Van To, requesting 3,186,000 VND to invest in a business.
  • Mr. Cho Van Dang, requesting 3,186,000 VND to make rice wrappers.
  • Mr. Que Van Tran, requesting 2,950,000 VND to raise livestock.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To create capital for various businesses such as making rice wrappers, fertilizer store, and raising livestock

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Hin

texts.en: Mr. Hin S. is a cow breeder and fisherman in Preak Takeo Village in Kandal Province. His second business of fishing has an obstacle now, as he does not have enough fish nets. So, he decided to ask for a loan to buy more fish nets, which he hopes will help him gather more fish and improve his living conditions. His wife, Mrs. Tum Saroeurn, is a farmer who can earn a small income with her plantation revenue. Mr. Hin S. is 50 years old and the father of seven children, four of whom are employed in different business activities, while the three remaining are attending high school. His wife is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more fish nets

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: Seng R., 58, is married and she lives with one of her five children in The Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 1979, she has been working on her rice field to earn a living and is able to make $1.30 per day. She is assisted by her children. Her husband, Nun Sok, 59, owns a plot of land growing vegetables to earn a profit of around $3 each day. She is asking for a loan of $400 to make two investments. She would like to invest $300 in her husband's farm, and also use $100 to purchase fertilizers for her rice farm. She sees these investments as opportunities that will be able to increase her daily income.

loans.use: To invest in farming

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Xinh Thi's Group

texts.vi:
chị Tô thị Xinh Ms 13050015 năm nay 32 tuổi, vợ chồng chị sinh được 2 con, cả 2 con chị đều nhỏ và đang đi học. Chồng chị là thợ lắp đặt điện thoại, còn chị mở cửa hàng kinh doanh bánh kẹo, nước giải khát tại nhà, nên mức thu nhập của gia đình chị cũng khá ổn định từ 170.000 VND đến 200.000 VND / ngày. chị đã tham gia vay vốn của chương trình qua một C. kỳ và hoàn trả rất tốt, C. kỳ này chị đăng ký vay mức 4.704.000 VND để đầu tư vào kinh doanh .Trong nhóm chị có các thành viên sau :

  • chị N. thị Hạnh Ms 13050014 đăng ký vay mức 3.360.000 VND để đi chợ buôn bán hoa quả
  • chị Tô thị Lan Ms 13050019 đăng ký vay mức 3.808.000 VND để kinh doanh hoa quả
  • chị Bùi thị Thành Ms 13050018 vay mức 4.704.000 VND để mua gỗ làm mộc
  • chị chị Vũ thị Tình Ms 13050013 vay mức 4.704.000 VND để đi chợ buôn bán thịt
  • chị Vũ thị Hiền Ms 13050017 vay mức 4.256.000 VND để làm bánh đa nem
  • chị Bùi thị Lam Ms 13050016 vay mức 4.704.000 VND để làm nghề tráng bánh đa nem
  • chị C. thị Thuỷ Ms 13050025 vay mức 4.704.000 VND để đi chợ và tráng bánh đa nem
texts.en:
Mrs. Xinh Thi T., ID 13050015, is a 32 year old woman. The couple has 2 children who are still small and going T. school. Her husband is a cable guy who works while she operates a small kiosk serving drinks and candies at home. The family’s income is stable, ranging from 170,000 T. 200,000 Vietnamese Dong per day. She joins a group T. make a loan and pays back on time. Later, she plans T. make another loan of 4,704,000 Vietnamese Dong T. further invest in her business. In her group, there are the following individuals: • Ms. Hanh Thi Nghiem, ID 13050019, borrowing 3,808,000 Vietnamese Dong T. sell fruits. • Ms. Lan Thi T., ID 13050019, borrowing 4,704,000 Vietnamese Dong T. sell fruits. • Ms. Thanh Thi B., ID 13050018, borrowing 4,256,000 Vietnamese Don T. sell meat. • Ms. Tinh Thi V., ID 13050017, borrowing 4,704,000 Vietnamese Dong T. operate a “Banh Da” kiosk. • Ms. Thuy Thi C., ID 13050025, borrowing 4,704,000 Vietnamese Dong T. operate a “Banh Da Nem” kiosk.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Drinking and Candy kiosk

loans.name: Muth

texts.en: Mr. Muth V., 39, lives in the Preak Ta Ong Ti Pie village in Kandal Province. He is a construction worker who can earn $3.50 a day to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Saom Lun, works as a mat maker to help support the family. Her business is going well, so Mrs. Saom Lun wants to expand it. Her husband, Mr. Muth V., is asking for a loan to buy more raw materials to make the mats. He hopes to increase the number of customers his wife has and improve his living conditions with this loan. He and his wife are pictured in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials to make mats.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo R., 23, sells ice to various businesses and restaurants in Kampong Chhnang where she lives with her husband, Chhay Li Houn, and her parents. In Cambodia, many businesses purchase ice each day for their customers, because they do not have refrigerators. Chhay Li Houn sells ice along with his wife and together they typically make $10 per day. They do not have any children and they are still living with Keo R.'s parents, because they are a very young couple. Keo R. has asked for a loan of $1200 to purchase a piece of farmland to grow rice for additional income for her family. She can rent the land out to other farmers and this will allow her to diversify her sources of income and improve her family's quality of life. Keo R. was unavailable for a photograph at the time of the interview, so her husband, Chhay Li Houn, is pictured above.

loans.use: Purchase farmland to rent out to farmers

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mrs Chea D. was born in 1969 and she now lives in Sampan Kraom Village in Kandal Province. She is a port seller in the local market and her husband, Mr Khoeng Chhoeurn, is a cow breeder who raises two cows. Mrs Chea D. has two children who are attending the local school.

Although Mrs Chea D. and her husband have two businesses, they still live in poor conditions. In order to improve this standard of living, Mrs Chea D. decided to ask for a loan to start pig breeding business. She will buy five pigs and the rest of the loan she will use to buy pig food.

loans.use: To start a pig breeding business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Koth

texts.en: Koth S., 36, is an entrepreneur who has businesses selling many kinds of food to the local people. She earns approximately $3 of profit per day. Her husband, Yoeun Nov, owns a plot of land for growing vegetables. On average, he sells the crops in the local market and is able to make around $3.50 per day. This couple has five children, one of whom sells used clothes at an open air market, three of whom are students and one other is married and no longer lives at home. Mrs. Koth is asking for a loan from of $200 to purchase a motorbike to transport vegetables to the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport vegetables to the market

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Xuân Thi Nguyên Group

texts.vi:
chị Nguyễn thị xuân Ms 13050001 năm nay 35 tuổi, chị là một cán bộ phụ nữ rất năng động và nhiệt tình với phong trào. Ngoài công việc ở cơ quan ra, về nhà chị còn chăn nuôi lợn, gà,công việc tuy bận rộn nhưng giúp chị năng động hơn, chị luôn giành thời gian chăm sóc 2 con, bởi 2 cháu vẫn còn nhỏ và đang đi học. Chồng chị hàng ngày đi làm thợ xây dựng nên mức thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị từ 150.000 VND đến 170.000 VND / ngày. Chị đã tham gia vay vốn qua một chu kỳ, chị thấy rất thích tham gia hình thức vay trả này của Bình Minh cdc. Do vậy chu kỳ này chị đăng ký vay mức 4.704.000 VND để chăn nuôi. Nhóm chị gồm các thành viên :

  • chị Nguyễn thị Sáu Ms 13050005 vay mức 4.256.000 VND để kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá và chăn nuôi
  • chị Tô thị Hà Ms 13050006 vay mức 4.256.000 VND để đi chợ hoa quả
  • chị Trần thị Tình Ms 13050003 vay mức 4.256.000 VND để chăn nuôi và nấu rượu
  • chị Đỗ thị Hồng Ms 13050004 vay mức 4.256.000 VND để đi chợ buôn hoa quả
texts.en:
Mrs. Xuan Thi Nguyen, ID 13050001, is a 35 year old woman. She is an active woman’s-rights officer. She is also raising pigs and chickens at home. Though busy, she always has time to take care of her 2 children, who are still small and attending school. Her husband is a construction worker. The family’s income ranges from 150,000 to 170,000 Vietnamese Dong per day. She joined a group borrowing money for 1 term. This time, she plans to make a loan of 4,704,000 Vietnamese Dong to invest in livestock. In her group, there are following individuals: • Ms. Sau Thi Nguyen, ID 13050005, borrowing 4,255,000 Vietnamese Dong to open a grocery store and invest in livestock. • Ms. Ha Thi To, ID 13050006, borrowing 4,256,000 Vietnamese Dong to sell fruits. • Ms. Tinh Thi Tran, ID 13050003, borrowing 4,256,000 Vietnamese Dong to invest in livestock and make wine. • Ms. Hong Thi Do, ID 13050004, borrowing 4,256,000 Vietnamese Dong to sell fruits

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: livestock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of silver-plated jewelry to retail in her community

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase haircare products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in products and materials for her small beauty salon.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación San Miguel Arcángel, Inc. (FSMA) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To start a small business by purchasing clothing, purses, and beauty products in bulk

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación San Miguel Arcángel, Inc. (FSMA) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy clothing to sell in the community

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To grow five small businesses, including a cafeteria and shoe store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To add new products to her mini-market so as to increase her sales volume and income

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación San Miguel Arcángel, Inc. (FSMA) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Spomenka

texts.en:
Spomenka is a 43 year old woman from the town of Doboj.  She is married and has one daughter.  Her husband has a full time job and earns a monthly salary of 450 KM.  They grow and sell vegetables and earn 200 KM monthly.

This is Spomenka's first loan from WWI and it is for 800 KM ($600).  She already owns some chickens and will use the loan to purchase more, which she will sell during the winter and thus expand their agriculture business.

loans.use: To buy more chickens

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok L. is 49 years old and works as rice farmer. She lives with four of her five children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 1979, she and her husband have been working on their rice field to earn a living and are able to make less than $1 each day. They told a loan officer that farmers are making less profit and need to worry about the weather conditions because most of them have no irrigation systems yet. People need to farm by depending on the sky and if there is no rain they risk damage to their rice crop. The couple are also aided by their children who contribute $50 a month to support the family. To double the family income, Mrs. Sok is asking a loan to raise ducks for eggs.

loans.use: To raise ducks for eggs.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Mom

texts.en: Mom P., 45, is a widow who lives in Kampong Chhnang province with her two children who both work at a local garment factory. She is a vegetable wholesaler who makes $2 per day in net income, while her children work at a garment factory and make a combined total of $160 per month, contributing to help support the household. Mom P. does not enjoy having her son work in the garment factory, though, and believes that there are better opportunities for him elsewhere. She has asked for a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike for her son to operate a motortaxi service instead of working in the factory. Mom P.'s son and daughter are pictured above with the motorbike that she plans to purchase with the loan.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her son

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mom D. has business renting rooms in her house to earn a living and is able to make $5 of profit per day. Her husband, Ngen Thorn, pictured above, drives a three-wheeled-vehicle called a "Tuk Tuk". He normally serves guests of the hotel and restaurants who need transportation or want to go on a city tour. Her husband Ngen Thon knows  a little English and that is why he can guide visitors around the city. On average, he makes $15 in revenue per day. People prefer to get a ride in a Tuk Tuk instead of a simple motorbike because it more relaxing and enjoyable.

Mrs. Mom would like a loan to replace an old and unreliable Tuk Tuk for her husband. The new Tuk Tuk will be more attractive to passengers.

loans.use: To purchase a new Tuk Tuk for her husband.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Bunh

texts.en:
Bunh P., 38, cuts firewood and sells it out of her home in Siem Reap where she lives with her husband, Chin Kut, and their nine children. She typically makes US$ 4 each day in profits and her family is also supported through her two children who work in construction, making US$ 6 per day. Another operates a motortaxi service, making US$ 4 per day.

Bunh P. has asked CREDIT for a loan of US$ 500 to help her son's business. She would like to replace her son's motorbike that is in constant need of repair, allowing him to earn more income and increase his profits. She believes this investment will cut down on the family's unnecessary expenses and can improve their standard of living in the long run.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike for her son

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase materials for tapestry-making purposes

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación San Miguel Arcángel, Inc. (FSMA) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Bun S., 35, is a widow who sells porridge for breakfast in Siem Reap where she lives with her five children. She typically makes US$ 15 each day in revenue and is aided in supporting the family by one of her children who works as a cleaner in a hotel. Another works as a vendor making US$ 5 per day.

Bun S. has asked CREDIT for a loan to help her increase her income and better support her family. She has asked for US$ 300 to purchase a stand at a local food market to sell porridge, rice, pork, beef, and other breakfast dishes. She believes that the market will be much more profitable than her home business and looks forward to expanding her customer base.

loans.use: Purchase a stand in the market

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Lach

texts.en: Lach S., 40, is a mother of two children and resides in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She works as a tailor from her home to earn a living and is able to make around $1.50 of profit per day. Normally, she purchases cloth from the garment factory to make gloves and sells them to the market. Her husband Bou Pov, 44, is a motor-taxi driver and is able to make $5 of profit per day. Mrs. Lach would like to loan of $400 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business. In the future, she wants to set up a grocery store to double the family income. (Mr. Bou is pictured with his motorbike outside their home)

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Soam

texts.en: Soam V., 44, is a housewife. She stays at home looking after the children and cooking food for the family members. Her husband, Chan Thoeun, 46, has been a blacksmith since 1993 and is able to make $10 each day. This couple has five children, three of whom are students, one of whom is too young to go to school and one other is married and no longer lives at home. Mrs. Saom would like a loan to purchase more blacksmith tools for her husband. (Mr. Chan Thoeun is pictured because Soam is not available.)

loans.use: To purchase more blacksmith tools for her husband

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Assadllah

texts.en:
Assadllah is married and the father of 6 children. He lives in district 15 of Kabul, Afghanistan. A. has a house near the street. All his neighbors have their houses and make shops in their houses, but he is unable to do this. He works in a governmental place in Kabul and has a small salary. He can barely support his family. He is unable to make any shop in his house.

Therefore, he has requested an individual loan of US $1100 with a term of 18 months to build 2 shops inside his house to rent out. He will take the rent money to help his family and make his house better each day because it has a good location.

He is happy with the loan process in his country for workers and for those who want to spent the money to benefit and help their families. In this poor country, he wants to say it is a big help for the people of this country. He wants to thank all lenders.

loans.use: To build 2 shops inside his house

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim B., 38, is an entrepreneur who purchases cloth from the garment factory and makes it into gloves to sell to the store near the market to earn approximately $1 of profit per day. Her husband, Tra Van, is a construction foreman and is able to make $5 per day. This couple has three children, one of whom is employed as garment worker and the other two are students. Mrs. Kim said in the future, she wants her children to take more classes so they can get better jobs. She is asking a loan of $1000 to purchase more construction tools for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase more construction tools for her husband

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Han

texts.en: Han C., 46, is an entrepreneur who buys cloth from the garment factory and makes it into gloves to sell to the store near the market to earn approximately $2 of profit per day. She is aided by her children who work as garment workers as well. Her husband, Chan Mony, 49, operates a motor-taxi business and is able to make $5 of profit per day. This couple told a loan officer that they spend around $70 on food and $5 on utilities. Mrs. Han would like a loan  to purchase more cloth to make gloves and also to start a new business to double the family income. She wants to purchase used clothes to sell in front of the garment factory.

loans.use: To purchase used clothes to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Nghim

texts.en:
Nghim S., 22, lives in Siem Reap with her husband, Im Ha, and their 2-year-old child. She is employed by a local company to clean and she makes US$ 50 per month, while her husband is a policeman making US$ 25 per month. The household is also supported by Nghim S.'s mother who runs a grocery stand and her niece who is a souvenir vendor in the market.

Nghim S. has asked CREDIT for a loan of US$ 1200 to purchase a motorbike for her commute to and from work. Right now inflation in Cambodia has been skyrocketing and the prices of gasoline and rice are very high. The local motortaxi services have felt this economic pressure and it has made prices of daily commutes rise. Nghim S. believes that this purchase will save her family money and can increase the family's ability to support itself.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike for her commute

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Norng

texts.en: Norng C. is 33 years old and resides with her child in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Since 1993, she has been working as garment factory worker to earn a living and is able to make US$3 each day. Her husband, Soam Yon, is a construction worker and sometime when he free he operates a motor-taxi business as well. On average, he makes about US$5 of profit per day from two activities.  Mrs. Norng would like to loan from Kiva via Credit, local partner, to replace an old and unreliable motorbike for her husband. (Soam is pictured with a motorbike)

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike..

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Chhoun

texts.en: This the fourth time that Mrs. Chhoun T. has asked for a loan to improve her business activities. She is a farmer who grows cabbage and garlic in her field, which is located in Preak Talai Village in Kandal Province. Her husband, Mr. Chea Ngov, is a cow breeder who raises two cows, and he also assists with his wife's business. Mrs. Chhoun T. is now facing a small problem with her plantation, because she does not have enough money to purchase more Chinese garlic to grow. Thus, Mrs. Chhoun T. is requesting a loan to for this purpose. She would use the rest of the loan to buy fertilizer, and fuel for her pump. Mrs. Chhoun T. is 49 years old and the mother of a child who is attending high school.

loans.use: To purchase more Chinese garlic, fertilizer, and fuel for her pump.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Pao

texts.en:
Mrs. Pao N. was born in 1956 and she now lives in Lvea Sor Kandal Village in Kandal Province. She owns a small store in the local market, where she sells clothes. Since her business is going well, Mrs. Pao N. wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to purchase more fashion clothes to re-sell to her customers.

Her husband, Mr. Erm Sroeurn, is a rice middleman who buys rice to keep in stock and re-sell later at better price. Mrs. Pao N. has two children. One is employed in a garment factory and can earn around $50 per month. The other helps her with her current business. Mrs. Pao N. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase more fashion clothes to re-sell to her customers.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Oem

texts.en:
Mrs. Oem L. was born in 1949, and she lives in Preak Ta Ong Ti Pie Village in Kandal Province. She makes mats for a living. Meanwhile, her husband, Mr. Pich Pov (pictured on the left of the photograph), is a wedding chef. Notably, her husband earns less money between June and September than he does during the balance of the year because there are fewer wedding ceremonies during those particular months; then again, her husband can earn more income from January to May and from October to December.

In Mrs. Oem L.'s business, she does not have enough raw materials to make mats, so she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. As such, with the requested loan proceeds, she will address her shortage of raw materials by purchasing inputs to make mats. Mrs. Oem L. notes that she has two children who assist her with the business.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials to make mats.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Saven

texts.en: Saven T., 35 , sells various kinds of fruits in the market and earns approximately US$10 each day. Her husband is a soldier and makes US$2 to help support the family. The couple has two children, one of whom is a soldier and the other is a student. Mrs. T. would like a loan from Kiva to increase the number of fruits she can sell to her growing customer base. She told to a loan officer that she spends around US$70 each month for food and US$5 for utilities and US$1.5 each day for her child's education.

loans.use: To increase the number of fruits she can sell

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en: Mrs. Nhem M. and her husband, Mr. Korng Ry, have a business of fishing, and live in Peam Ta Ek Village in Kandal Province. They are currently facing a problem because they have an old boat which they can no longer use for fishing. Mrs. Nhem M. decided to ask for a loan to buy a boat, and she would use the rest of the loan to buy more fish nets to catch more fish. Mrs. Nhem M. is 47 years old and the mother of five children:  one is a fisherman and the others are attending school. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a boat and more fish nets

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Ou

texts.en: Ou K., 29, is a widow living in Siem Reap that sells grocery products out of her home for US$7 per day in income. She lives with her younger sister who is employed at a nearby hospital. Ou K. has asked CREDIT for a loan of US$1000 to purchase more grocery products to meet her growing customer demand and diversify her product options. She would like to continue expanding her business in the future, as well, and sees this loan as only the first step in improving her enterprise.

loans.use: Increase grocery inventory

loans.name: San

texts.en: This is the second loan that Mrs. San T. has asked for to improve her living conditions. She lives in Ampov Prey Muoy Village in Kandal Province. She is a cow breeder who raises only one cow because she does not have enough money to buy more cows. She is a 41 year old widow with three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while another one is a waiter in a restaurant in a provincial town. The youngest one, 16, is attending school. Since Mrs. San T.'s eldest child works far from home, she has to spend a lot of money on transportation. So, she decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings, and buy a new motorbike for her child to travel to work. She hopes to increase her income and save more money with this loan.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for her child

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Ron

texts.en: Mrs. Ron R. lives in Khsom Village in Kandal Province. She owns a grocery store in the local market. In this business, she can earn around $6 a day to support her family. Since her business is going well, Mrs. Ron R. decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery products for her inventory. Her husband, Eith Kunthea, helps her in her grocery business. Mrs. Ron R. is a 31-year-old woman without any children. Mrs. Ron R. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products for her inventory.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: This will be the second loan for Mrs. Sam M., who is using the funds to improve her business. She lives in Preak Daung Village in Kandal Province. She is a 68 year old widow with two children who both work as construction workers. Mrs. Sam M. is a farmer who harvests twice a year; during the rainy season she cultivates rice, and during the dry season she grows vegetables. Mrs. Sam M. now faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to hire a laborer with oxen to plow her rice field. Therefore, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose, and she will also use it to buy more rice seeds.

loans.use: To hire a laborer with oxen to plow her rice field, and buy rice seeds

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Almas

texts.en: Almas is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Kalbadjar region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan and has settled in Baku city. She was born in 1955. Almas has been in the bread-baking business for 10 years. Now she needs a loan of US$ 1200 to buy more of the necessary products for baking  bread.

loans.use: to buy more of the necessary raw materials for baking  bread

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Anwar's Group

texts.en:
Anwar baji is the wife of H. A. and lives in Pakistan in the city of Lahore in a district named Walton. She has been living in this city for the last 30 years. She is the mother of six children: three boys and three girls. Her eldest son is a mechanic and repairs vehicles. The next eldest to him is in 9th standard. The younger one is in 5th standard. Her eldest daughter couldn't get an education because of her weak mind. The next to her is in 10th standard. Her youngest daughter is in 8th standard.

Anwar baji's husband is a driver by profession. Anwar baji is a housewife but she sews clothes also. She has been in this line of work for the last 20 years. She has successfully repaid her three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to repair her husband's small truck.

She is joined in her loan group by several more members. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Zubaida baji wants a loan to buy wood for her shutter business. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy livestock to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair a small truck for her husband

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Sang

texts.en: Sang S. L., 42, lives in Siem Reap with her husband, Doeun Samuth, and their four children. She sells a variety of grocery products out of her home, making US$10 per day of income, while her husband is a tuk-tuk driver typically making US$5 per day. One of their sons operates his own motortaxi service, as well, and can provide US$4 per day for the family. Sang S. L. has asked CREDIT for a loan of US$500 to purchase another motorbike for the family's transportation needs. Any leftover money after the purchase of the motortaxi will be used to expand the grocery inventory and help to improve her business.

loans.use: Purchase motorbike for family commute; Increase grocery store inventory

loans.name: Zaur

texts.en: Zaur is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Kalbadjar region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan and is settled in Baku city. He was born in 1976. Zuer is married, has one child. Fifteen years ago he started a business in video recording. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy the necessary video equipment to continue his business.

loans.use: to buy the necessary equipment for video recording

loans.name: Saira's Group

texts.en:
Saira B. M. is the widow of B. M. and lives in the Walton area of Lahore City, Pakistan. Saira has been living here for the last twelve years and has been married for the last 35 years. She is the mother of four children: two boys and two girls. Her eldest son and daughter are married. Her youngest son is a mechanic and works in a workshop. Her youngest daughter completed her 12th standard and is ready to take college admissions. Her eldest son has a workshop where he sells spare parts. Saira B. M. is a housewife and does the household work to take care of her family. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a second loan to buy spare parts for her son's workshop.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members: Samia P. wants a loan to buy material (beads, cloth, sketches) to make decoratively embroidered dresses. Kosar M. Shahbaz wants a loan to buy clothing to resell. Bilquis G. R. wants a loan to buy material (beams) for her shuttering business. Elizabeth S. M. wants a loan to buy spare vehicle parts.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for her son's workshop

loans.name: Mrs. Sim Sarin's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank, which is comprised of 22 people, is located in Slab Ta Aon Village in Kandal Province. Most of the group members are married, and they will use their portion of the loan proceeds for different purposes.

To illustrate, Mrs. Sim S. is the village bank president, though she also sells fruit at the local market. Since her business has been doing well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy different kinds of fruit to meet her customers' demands. Mrs. Sim S.'s husband, Mr. Chea Sun, is a construction worker who makes approximately $3.50 per day to support their family. Mrs. Sim S. is 45 years old, and she is the mother of five children. One of her children is employed at a garment factory and earns approximately $65 per month, three of her children attend school, and her youngest child (a 2-year-old) is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To expand a fruit-selling business by purchasing a variety of fruit to meet her customers' demands.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Gulzar

texts.en:
Gulzar is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Fuzuli region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan. She has settled in the Absheron region. She is the mother of 4 children.

Gulzar has been in the clothing business for 5 years. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy clothes to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Irshad Rani's Group

texts.en:
Irshad rani baji is the wife of B. M. and lives in the city named Lahore, in a district called named Walton, Pakistan. She has been married for the last 25 years. She is the mother of five children: four boys and one girl.

Irshad baji's brother has a cigarette shop. Her elder son works with her brother. The next eldest is in 10th standard. The one after him works in a factory. Her younger son wants to be a tailor. Her daughter completed her 10th standard and presently she is free and does household work.

Irshad baji's husband is a daily wage laborer. Irshad baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She has successfully repaid her three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more cigarettes for her brother's cigarette shop.

She is joined in her loan group by several more members. Mumtaz baji wants a loan to buy wood for her shutter business. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics for her beauty parlor. Bashiran baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled vehicle). Nasreen and Shabnam baji each want a loan to buy spare parts for vehicles.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy cigarettes to re-sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Lubugumu Twekembe Women's Group

texts.en:
Jane K. is the chairperson of Lubugumu Twekembe women's group that has been in existence for 5 years. She is a married woman with 10 children of whom one is at Makerere University doing a course in banking while the rest are in lower classes. She also helps to cater for school fees for many cousins that stay in the village.

Jane has two businesses. She is a farmer growing mostly bananas, cassava and sweet potatoes as well as making local alcohol to sell to bars around her and in the city centers. With the local brew, she makes waragi and tonto whereby she prepares spear grass that is mixed and mingled with the ripe juice-producing bananas (mabidde). The juice that comes out is put into jerry cans. Sorghum is mixed and covered in a previously dug hole for a week or two and the end result is Tonto. For waragi, the tonto is again put into metal cans and placed on a fire with a tube that connects to two more metal cans from which the boiled tonto moves and is cooled to make waragi.

In a week, Jane can make and sell 10 jerry cans of tonto and 10 of waragi as she also sells to her daily customers who drink at her home. Jane needs a loan to be able to buy more bananas, a metallic can, and firewood for her local brewing business.

loans.use: to buy more bananas, a metallic can, and firewood

loans.name: Sadia's Group

texts.en:
Sadia I. M. is the wife of I. M. and lives in the Walton area of Lahore City, Pakistan. She has been living in this area for the last seven years. She is the mother of a four-year-old daughter. Sadia baji's husband is a painter, and he paints offices, doors, windows, and walls. For the last four years he has also run a scrap business. Sadia baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She has successfully repaid four loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more scrap parts (iron, wastepaper, and bottles) for her husband to resell.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Niamatay M. Ashraf wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business. Rani S. M. wants a loan to buy a donkey cart. Bilquis N. P. M. wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motorized vehicle). Maryam W. M. wants a loan to buy electric supplies (tubes, switches and switch boards) for her electric shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy scrap items (iron, wastepaper, bottles)  to resell

loans.name: Shamim M. Razaq Group

texts.en:
Shamim M. Razaq is the wife of M. Razaq and lives in the Walton area of Lahore City, Pakistan. She has been living in this area for the last five years. She is the mother of seven children: five daughters and two sons. Her eldest daughter is married. Three of her other daughters are in school, in the 9th, 7th, and 6th standard respectively. Both of her sons are in the 10th standard at school. Her husband is a driver by profession. Shamim baji used to work in a school, but her health and the hard working conditions kept her from continuing this job. Instead, she is requesting a loan to start a new vegetable selling business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Sharifan H. M. wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business. Suraiya I. and Najma A. K. each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy vegetables to start a new vegetable selling business

loans.name: Yawovi Mawulom

texts.fr:
Monsieur M. Yawovi Mawulom est né le 30 novembre 1978 à Mission Tové dans la préfecture de Zio. Il est célibataire avec un enfant. Il a ouvert un magasin «  MINI PHARMA DIEU EST GRAND » de vente des produits génériques  dans le quartier d’Agoè à Lomé. Son objectif en exerçant cette activité est de sauver des vies humaines à coût réduit.
Ce premier crédit qu’il sollicite lui permettra d’aller s’approvisionner au Ghana en produits génériques pour un total de sept cartons afin de pouvoir servir la population. Ainsi avec le revenu de cette activité, elle pourra aussi subvenir à ses besoins.
texts.en:
Mr. Yawovi Mawulom M. was born on November 30, 1978 in Mission Tové in Zio Prefecture. He is single and has a child. He opened a store called “MINI PHARMA DIEU EST GRAND” selling generic pharmaceutical products in the Agoè district of Lomé. The objective of his work is to save human lives at a reduced cost. This first loan that he is requesting will enable him to get supplies of generic pharmaceuticals in Ghana totaling seven boxes in order to be able to serve the people. And thus, with the income from this business, he will also be able to provide for himself.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy generic pharmaceuticals

loans.name: Zibula Atudde Kyetume Group

texts.en:
Milly N. is the chairperson of Zibula Atudde women's group in Kyetume in the Mukono district. She is married with four children, three of which are in school. She also cares for the three orphans of her late brother and sister. She is a business woman and a farmer, mostly growing cabbage, cassava, and matooke. She sells the produce at the Kyetume Central Market. She would like to be able to transport her produce to the city for more profits.

Milly also has a bar that she started six years ago. She sells local brew, a delicacy for most of her customers, as well as beer, wine, spirits, and soda. Milly and her husband make the brew with the help of their children. She prefers to sell the local brew because she determines the pricing, unlike other spirits where the pricing is standard.

Milly needs a loan to help buy more waragi and tonto for her bar and to pay school fees for her children, who are soon beginning their third term.

loans.use: To help buy more waragi and tonto for her bar and pay school fees.

loans.name: Butasingwa, Zibula Atudde Group

texts.en:
Betty B. is the leader of her group in the Zibula atudde women's group of Kyetume. She is married and her 6 children are all still in school. The main challenge she has is paying their school fees, and that is why she joined her lending group.

Betty is a businesswoman who sells shoes of all kinds from the Kyetume Central market and from home. She has also been a tailor for 6 years, a duty she still performs from her home; she deals mainly in women's and children's clothes. She also keeps cows and pigs, which has helped her in times of need--she would sell a pig and milk to supplement her savings to pay school fees or invest in her businesses. Betty needs a loan to help her buy more shoes to sell and more material for her tailoring business.

loans.use: Betty Butasingwa needs a loan to help her buy more shoes to sell and more material for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Afoutouhlin

texts.fr:
Né le 24 juin 1977 à Lomé, monsieur K. Afoutouhlin est un jeune célibataire très endurant qui a ouvert son bar « BOOM RANG » dans la ville de Lomé. Etant donné qu’il est en chômage il a rassemblé ses fonds et a fait une étude se son milieu pour voir ce qui peut être bien consommé par la population de son quartier. Après cette étude il a ouvert son bar en 2007 et vend très bien.
Ce premier crédit qu’il sollicite lui permettra d’augmenter les produits dans son stock et de pouvoir bien servir ses clients.
A cet effet, il sollicite ce crédit pour s’approvisionner avec 65 casiers de bière et 20 casiers de sucrerie.
texts.en:
Born on June 24, 1977 in Lomé, Mr. Afoutouhlin K. is a young, determined, single gentleman who opened his bar “BOOM RANG” in the city of Lomé. Given that he was unemployed, he gathered his funds and performed a study of his community to see what services were in demand in his area. After this study, he opened his bar in 2007 and is selling successfully. The request of his first loan will allow him to increase his stock of products and better serve his clients. For this reason he is requesting a loan to add 65 cases of beer and 20 cases of candy to his inventory.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of beverages to supply the bar

loans.name: Coi Thi

texts.vi: Chị Hà thị Côi năm nay 38 tuổi. Trước khi tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương kinh tế gia đình chị gặp rất nhiều khó khăn do chồng chị mất sớm một mình chị phải nuôi 2 con nhỏ. Năm đầu tiên tham gia vào Quỹ chị xin vay mức vốn 2.000.000đ để đầu tư vào việc đóng gạch bán cho người dân địa phương cho thu nhập 400.000đ/ tháng. Đến nay công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho 3 mẹ con chị Côi là đóng gạch ban. Ngoài huy động nguồn nhân lực của gia đình chị Côi còn phải thuê thêm 1 công nhân để đảm bảo đủ số lượng gạch bán cho bà con địa phương. Không chỉ đónggạch bán để tăng thêm thêm thu nhập cho gia đình chị Côi còn kết hợp chăn nuôi thêm lợn, gà và nuôi cá. Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư mua nguyên liệu  sản xuất gạch và chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Coi Thi H. is 38 years old. She faced many difficulties before joining the TYM fund because her husband had passed away early, leaving her with 2 small children. She made the first loan of 2,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to invest in the manufacturing of bricks. This business usually brings in 400,000 Vietnamese Dong per month. Until now, the family’s main income still came from making bricks. The business has since expanded and she can now hire another worker. To increase her moneymaking prospects, she raises pigs, chickens, and fish. She plans to make the next loan of 15,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to buy supplies and food for the animals.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: livestock

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Sou

texts.en:
Sou S. Oa, 49, has a business selling brooms around Phnom Penh city and earns approximately US$8 each day. His wife, Sok Saren, stays at home making the brooms for her husband to sell (pictured). The broom are made from a long grass which grows in the forest. People that live in the outskirts, especially along the railway, have businesses making brooms and selling them throughout Phnom Penh city. The couple began making and selling brooms in 1998. They have three children, all of whom are employed as garment factory workers.

She told a loan officer that every month she needs to spend around US$80 on food and US$15 on utility. Mr. Sou is requesting a loan from Kiva via CREDIT, Kiva's local partner, to purchase the long grass in bulk. This will save money and allow his wife to increase the number of brooms that she can make. The couple plan to distribute the brooms to other small sellers. In the future, if possible, Mr. Sou wants to have a small truck to transport the brooms.

loans.use: To purchase the long grass in bulk that is required to make brooms.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Chiên năm nay 48 tuổi gia đình chị hiện có 4 con trong đó có hai con đã  trưởng thành. Tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương vòng vốn đầu chị vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi, sau đó nhận thấy công việc kinh doanh dịch vụ ăn uống cũng có thể đem lại thu nhập cao nên các vòng vốn sau gia đình chị đã đầu tư vốn để kinh doanh cửa hàng ăn.  Hiện nay hai vợ chồng chị Chiên đều đang kinh doanh cửa hàng ăn và kết hợp chăn nuôi thêm lợn, gà tại gia đình. Với thái độ phục vụ nhiệt tình cửa hàng của gia đình chị luôn thu hút được lượng khách ngày một đông. Tận dụng nguồn thức ăn của cửa hàng công việc chăn nuôi của gia đình cũng có nhiều thuận lợi. Với thu nhập ổn định từ chăn nuôi và kinh doanh  kinh tế gia đình chị đã ổn định hơn. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ để đầu tư mở rộng kinh doanh và chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
This year Ms. Nguyen Thi C. is 48 years of age; her family consists of 4 children, 2 of which are grown. She has been a part of this organization, using her first initial loan to invest in livestock. After raising farm animals, she realized that the restaurant business would bring in and improve the family’s income. Since then, she has been borrowing subsequent loans in which she used to invest in a restaurant. Presently, Ms. C. and her husband both run the family's restaurant while raising pigs and chickens at the same time. The restaurant is known for providing good customer service and the number of people coming in to eat is growing every day. Any leftover food from the restaurant is used to feed her livestock. The family income has improved and since been stable from both businesses of raising farm animals and running a restaurant. She is requesting a loan of 20.000.000d in which she plans to use to expand her restaurant and her farm.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business and rasing

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Trước khi tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương thu nhập của gia đình chị Ngân chủ yếu dựa vào chăn nuôi và trồng trọt. Với số vốn vay 2.000.000đ của vòng vốn đầu tiên khi tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương chị Ngân cũng sử dụng để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi cho thu nhập 500.000đ/ tháng. Sau một thời gian sử dụng vốn vay hiệu quả cùng với nguồn vốn huy động thêm từ anh em bạn bè gia đình chị đã đầu tư mua máy say sát gạo về phục vụ cho nhu cầu của người dân địa phương. Hiện nay công việc hàng ngày của chị Ngân là làm máy say sát và chăn nuôi còn chồng chị thì đi làm thợ xây. Với mức thu nhập ổn định 3.000.000đ /tháng và sự hỗ trợ của người con hiện đang lao động tại nước ngoài nên ngoài việc hoàn trả vốn cho Quỹ và chi tiêu trong gia đình anh chị còn tiết kiệm để tiếp tục đầu tư phát triển kinh tế gia đình. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ để tiếp tục đầu tư cho kinh doanh và chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Before becoming a member of this organization, Ms. N. only source of income for her family was raising livestock and providing child care services. Her first loan was used as an investment in raising livestock, averaging in 500.000d/month. She saw a success with the loan she receive for her business. She was able to used the profits in which she made along with the help from friends and family to invest in buying a wheat processing machine to service the need of the people in her community. Presently, Ms. N. every day job is to process wheat and raise farm animals while her husband works in the construction field. The family’s income has been steady at 3.000.000d/month. She also received financial support from one of her children who lives in a another country. Besides paying off the loan in which she received from the organization, she is able to save some money for her family. This next loan she is requesting an amount of 20.000.000d to continue her business and raising farm animals.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Ibrahim Abilou

texts.fr:
Monsieur M. T. Ibrahim Abilou est né le 3 mars 1976 à Lomé. Il est célibataire et a commencé son magasin de vente des produits congelés dans le quartier Agoè Zongo où la densité de la population est forte. Cette activité lui procure beaucoup de revenu car il a réduit le prix de vente pour attirer plus de clients à acheter auprès de lui. 
Il n’a jamais bénéficié du crédit auprès de WAGES et sollicite ce premier crédit pour acquérir un congélateur et d’autres accessoires de commerce pour pouvoir agrandir son commerce.
texts.en:
Mr. Ibrahim Abilou M. T. was born on March 3rd, 1976 in Lomé. He is single and has opened a store to sell frozen products in the area of Agoé Zongo where the population density is very high. This business earns him good income as he has lowered his prices to attract more clients to his store. He has never before taken advantage of a loan from WAGES and is now requesting his first loan to purchase a freezer and other business accessories to grow his company.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of a freezer and frozen products

loans.name: Bui Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Hậu năm nay 25 tuổi, gia đình chị hiện có 2 con còn nhỏ. Tuy còn trẻ nhưng chị Hậu đã có 6 năm kinh nghiệm trong lĩnh vực buôn bán nhỏ. Ngay từ khi mới bắt đầu tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương chị đã sử dụng vốn vay để đầu tư cho công việc kinh doanh của gia đình và cho thu nhập 500.000đ/ tháng. Anh Điểu chồng chị hàng ngày cũng tham gia công việc kinh doanh cùng vợ nên công việc kinh doanh của gia đình rất thuận lợi. Đến nay qua một thời gian sử dụng vốn hiệu quả thu nhập của gia đình chị đã tăng lên và đạt mức bình quân 2.000.000đ/ tháng. Kết hợp với  chăn nuôi  kinh tế của gia đình chị ngày càng ổn định hơn. Vì thế chị cũng có điều kiện hơn trong việc chăm sóc và đầu tư cho các con ăn học.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay  10.000.000đ để đầu tư thêm vốn để kinh doanh, buôn bán.
texts.en:
Ms. Hai is 25 years, she has 2 small children. Even though she is young, Ms. Hai has already had 6 years of experience doing a variety of small businesses. Since becoming a member of this organization, she has been using the loans she received to invest in the family’s business, averaging then 500.000d/month. Mr. Dieu, her husband, also work with her making it easier to run the business together. She has seen a huge success after doing business for some time; her income has increase to an average of 2.000.000d/month. Combining the family’s business and raising farm animals, their income has been stable. The family’s steady flow of income has provided an opportunity for her to invest into her children’s education. This next loan, she is requesting an amount of 10.000.000d to invest into a variety of trades.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising and business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Dao Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Hồi năm nay 31 tuổi. Gia đình chị hiện có hai con đang tuổi đến trường. Hiện nay hai vợ chồng chị đều kinh doanh hoa quả tại chợ. Hàng ngày chồng chị đi lấy hoa quả tại các đại lý lớn về để chị bán lại cho các cửa hàng bán lẻ tại chợ huyện và phục vụ nhu cầu tiêu thụ của bà con địa phương. Ngoài một cửa hàng hoa quả lớn bán tại chợ gia đình chị còn bán hàng trực tiếp cho người tiêu dùng tại nhà. Vì thế để phục vụ tốt nhu cầu của khách hàng gia đình chị phải thuê một nhân công chuyên vận chuyển hàng hoá cho các cửa hàng. Để tăng thu nhập cho gia đình ngoài thời gian bán hàng chị còn chăn nuôi thêm lợn, gà tại nhà. Với nguồn thu nhập ổn định từ kinh doanh 4.000.000đ/ tháng và nguồn thu từ chăn nuôi gia đình chị Hội là một trong những hộ gia đình có kinh tế khá tại thôn. 
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ để tiếp tục đầu tư vào kinh doanh hoa quả.
texts.en:
Ms. H. is 31 years of age. She has two children who are school-age. Presently, she and her husband does business selling fruits and produce at the local market. Everyday her husband picks up fruits and produce from the bigger businesses in bulk to bring home to sell to the locals in her community. Besides selling fruits and vegetables at her home, she also sells them at the local market. To provide better service, she also hired an extra hand to help deliver her products directly to her customers. To increase her family’s income, she also raises pigs and chickens at home. Her present income is 4.000.000d/month in which she received from her business; not to include the income from raising farm animals. Her family is considered one of the successful family in her town. This next loan, she is requesting a loan of 20.000.000d to continue to invest in her fruits and vegetables business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mom S. is a 61-year-old widowed teacher who lives with her two children in Phnom Penh. Typically, she is able to earn approximately $2 per day, and her daughter, Sin Kalyan, earns approximately $5 per day as a port staff member. Her other child is a photographer in a photo center in Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Mom is asking for a loan to purchase a digital camera for her son so that he can use the camera in his free time (i.e., when he is not working at the photo center). She is confident that her son will use the camera to generate additional profits to support their family.

loans.use: To purchase a digital camera for her son to enable him to generate greater income

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Wazaretou

texts.fr:
La cliente est née le 20 septembre 1965 à Ayengre dans la préfecture de Sotouboua, localité dans laquelle abondent les ignames. Elle est mariée et a 4 enfants. Depuis 2004, elle a commencé le commerce de vente ciment dans son quartier. La quantité de son stock attire beaucoup de clients et de cela elle tire beaucoup de revenus.

Actuellement compte tenu des échos de pénurie de ciments, elle souhaite en passer et sollicite ce premier crédit pour acheter 3 tonnes de ciments.
texts.en:
The client was born on 20 Septembeer 1965 in Ayengre in the prefecture of Sotouboua, an area where yams grow in abundance. She is married and has 4 children. Since 2004, she has run a business selling cement in her district. The quantity of her stock attracts many customers, and she draws a large income from this. Currently, having taken note of talk about a shortage of cement, she hopes to ensure the survival of her business, and is asking for her first loan to buy 3 tonnes of cement.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy three tons of cement

loans.name: Bejzada

texts.en: Bejzada Huskić was born 1956  and she is from the  village of Sjenina. Her husband works in Italy and his salary is 1000 KM. Bejzada has two children; her son is unemployed and her daughter is in her second year of secondary school. Bejzada will use this loan in the amount of 1200 KM to buy a cow. Now, she has a horse and her wish is  to produce food for cattle.

loans.use: To buy a cow

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Faiel

texts.en:
Faiel is married with 5 children. He is 36 years old. He is an educated man. He has a clothes shop and he has been involved in this business for more than 7 years. One of his brothers helps Faiel. His brother is also married. They work together, and he has always tried to enlarge his business because this business is supporting 2 families.

When he found AFSG in Kabul, he requested an individual loan of US$1075 to import more clothes. He wants to enlarge his shop to improve his business and make a good monthly income for these 2 families.

He is happy with this loan process. He wants to thank both Kiva and AFSG for making this process in this country. He wishes to become successful and open another shop after one year for his brother. He is happy, and he would like to thank Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To import more clothes and enlarge his shop

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mao H. is a 55-year-old married man who lives with his wife in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. This couple has seven children, only one of whom is still a student. Since 1991, he has been able to earn approximately $2 per day from his motor-taxi business. At the same time, he is aided financially by his children, who generate income from their involvement in the construction and tailoring industries. In addition, his wife, Sin Sam Art, who is 51 years old, has a business where she sells vegetables in the market, thereby earning approximately $3 per day.

Mr. Mao is requesting a loan to purchase a motorbike for one of his children so that the child can operate a motor-taxi. In the future, he plans to open a shop to enable his daughter to run a tailoring service.

loans.use: To enable one of his children to get into the motor-taxi business by purchasing a motorbike for the child

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Yawo

texts.fr:
Monsieur B. Yawo est né en 1984 à Wagba. Il est marié et père de trois (3) enfants. Il a ouvert depuis 2002 sa boutique de vente des produits de premières nécessités dans le quartier d’Agoè au nord de Lomé. Le premier crédit qu’il a obtenu lui a permis de réaménager sa boutique et de bien s’installer. 
Ce second crédit qu’il sollicite lui permettra d’acheter 10 bidons d’huile, 10 cartons de spaghetti et 5 sacs de riz et 8 cartons de laits. Avec ce nouveau stock, il pourra mieux vendre et tirer de revenu afin de pouvoir prendre en charge sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Yawo B. was born in 1984 in Wagba. He is married and has three (3) children. In 2002, he opened a store selling basic need goods in the Agoè district north of Lomé. The first loan he obtained allowed him to reorganize his store and to set it up properly. This second loan that he is asking for will allow him to buy 10 cans of oil, 10 boxes of spaghetti, 5 bags of rice, and 8 cartons of milk. With this new stock, he will be able to sell better and earn enough income to be able to take care of his family.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell basic need goods

loans.name: Ayeba Komgba

texts.fr:
Dame B. Ayeba Komgba est née le 31 décembre 1966 à Kpangalan au nord du Togo. Elle est veuve et a trois enfants à charge. Depuis 1988, elle a commencé le commerce de produits génériques à Lomé. Actuellement son souci est de trouver les moyens pour pouvoir subvenir aux besoins scolaires de ses enfants. 
A cet effet, elle sollicite ce second crédit pour refaire son stock afin de pouvoir bien vendre et  dégager des revenus avant la rentrée  scolaire prochaine.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ayeba Komgba B. was born on December 31, 1966 in Kpangalan in the north of Togo. She is a widow and is raising three children. Back in 1988, she began selling generic products in Lomé. Presently, her worry is to find sufficient means to pay the school expenses for her children.

With this in mind, she is requesting this second loan to complete her stock so that she can make a lot of sales and have higher earnings before the beginning of the new school year.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of generic products for re-sale

loans.name: Biova Group

texts.fr:
L’association BIOVA est un groupe de solidarité crée par deux femmes dynamiques dans le quartier d’Agoè. Ces femmes exercent des activités commerciales différemment. La première vend la boisson locale et la seconde est une coiffeuse et vend aussi des produits de beauté. 
Elles ont une fois bénéficié du crédit et on bien remboursé. Ce second crédit que cette association sollicite lui permettra de s’approvisionner avec 3 bidons de boisson locale et trois cartons de neutralisant et de produits de beauté.
texts.en:
The BIOVA association is a joint group created by two dynamic women in the Agoè district. These women run different commercial activities. The first sells local drinks and the second is a hairstylist and also sells cosmetics. They have already benefited from one loan and repaid it without incident. This second loan that this association is asking for will allow them to supply themselves with 3 bottles of local drinks and 3 boxes of neutralizing shampoo and cosmetics.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy three bottles of local Sodabi drinks and cosmetics

loans.name: Adiza

texts.fr:
Madame D. Adiza est née le 27 août 1973 à Sotouboua dans la région centrale du Togo. Elle est mariée et mère de deux (2) enfants. Depuis 1996, elle vend des produits de premières nécessités dans le quartier d’Agoè au nord de la ville de Lomé. Son lieu d’approvisionnement est le grand marché de Lomé, marché dans lequel elle achète à un prix moindre. 
Ce premier crédit qu’elle lui permettra de refaire son stock par l’achat de 5 sacs de riz, 24 cartons de savons et 10 cartons de tomate.
texts.en:
Mrs. Adiza D. was born on August 27, 1973 in Sotouboua in the central region of Togo. She is married and the mother of two children. Since 1996, she has been selling staple items in the district of Agoè in the north of the city of Lomé. She buys her merchandise in the big open-air market of Lomé, since it is there that she can buy at the lowest price.

This first loan that she is requesting will allow her to complete her stock with the purchase of 5 sacks of rice, 24 cases of soap, and 10 cases of tomatoes.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of staple items for re-sale

loans.name: Akossiwoa

texts.fr: Née le 05 avril 1981 à Djagblé une petite localité à la périphérie de la ville de Lomé, madame A. Akossiwoa est mère de deux enfants. Revendeuse de fourniture scolaire elle à pris l’initiative d’augmenter sont stock pour cette rentrée scolaire et aussi diversifier sa marchandise. Son meilleur atout est qu’elle se situe géographiquement dans l’enceinte d’une école. Ainsi elle a besoin de ce premier crédit pour acheter de divers cahiers.
texts.en:
Born on April 5, 1981 in Djagblé, a little place on the periphery of the city of Lomé, Mrs. Akossiwoa A. is the mother of two children. She sells school supplies and has taken the initiative to add to her stock for the beginning of the school year and also to diversify her merchandise.

Her trump card is that she is located right by a schoolyard. Thus, she needs this first loan to buy various exercise books.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of school supplies for re-sale

loans.name: Ablavi Ahoefa

texts.fr:
Madame A. Ablavi est née à Lomé le 08 mai 1962. Elle est mariée et mère de deux enfants. C’est une femme vaillante qui cherche à prospérer. Elle est revendeuse de pagne et elle exerce cette activité depuis 2000.
C’est bientôt la rentrée scolaire. Astucieuse elle veut orienter la vente vers les tissus qui servent à confectionner les tenues scolaires. Elle a donc besoin de ce premier prêt pour acheter 30 rouleaux de 6 pièces de pagne.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ablavi A. was born in Lomé on May 8, 1962. She is married and the mother of two children. She is a courageous woman who is trying hard to prosper. She sells "pagnes" (lengths of colorful African print cloth), a business she has been in since the year 2000.

Since children will soon be going back to school, she has cleverly decided to sell the kinds of cloth that are used to make school uniforms. She needs this, her first loan, to buy 30 rolls of 6 pieces of "pagne".

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cloth and "pagnes"

loans.name: Komlan

texts.fr:
Monsieur A. Komlan est tailleur. Il est âgé de 47 ans, est marié et père de 3 enfants. Il exerce son activité depuis 1989. Bientôt c’est la rentrée scolaire. Il sera sollicité pour la confection des uniformes scolaires. Etant donné qu’il vend aussi des articles de merceries, la demande va croître. Son activité ne consiste pas seulement à confectionner des habits pour vendre mais aussi former les jeunes qui veulent bien évoluer dans ce domaine très passionné.
Il aura à cet effet besoin de ce crédit pour l’achat des articles de merceries et de tissus.
texts.en:
Mr. Komlan A. is a tailor. He is 47 years old, married, and has 3 children. He has run his business since 1989. Soon the school year will start and he will be asked to make school uniforms. Given that he also sells haberdashery items, the demand for his goods will increase. His business does not consist only of making ready-to-wear clothes, but also includes training youths who are very passionate and want to develop their skills in this field. He is therefore in need of this loan to buy haberdashery items and fabrics.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric and haberdashery items

loans.name: Akouvi

texts.fr:
Née le 15 août 1973 à Assanhoun, ville située à 80 Km de la ville de Lomé, madame Akouvi A. vit aujourd’hui à Lomé après avoir passé son adolescence à Assanhoun au côté de sa maman qui l’initia au commerce de charbon. Elle est mariée aujourd’hui et est mère d’un enfant. Depuis qu’elle s’est installée à Lomé 1998, elle vend du charbon de bois.
Elle à besoin de ce premier crédit pour augmenter son stock de charbon d’un montant de 150.000FCFA.
texts.en:
Born on August 15, 1973 in Assanhoun, a town situated 80 km from the city of Lomé, Mrs. Akouvi A. now lives in Lomé after having spent her adolescence in Assanhoun with her mother who taught her how to sell charcoal. She is now married and is the mother of one child. Ever since she came to live in Lomé in 1998, she has been selling charcoal.

She needs this, her first loan, to increase her stocks of charcoal by the amount of 150,000 FCFA.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of charcoal for re-sale

loans.name: Koffi Mensah Edem

texts.fr:
Monsieur Z. Koffi Mensah Edem, âgé de 27 ans est célibataire sans enfant. Il n’a pas fait de longues études. Il a eu très tôt le goût du commerce et s’est lancé depuis 2002. Ses pas l’ont conduit à installer un débit de boisson dans un coin animé de son quartier. Son affaire n’a pas traîné à prospérer.
Il se trouve souvent confronté à un manque de stock. Ainsi il a besoin de ce premier crédit pour augmenter son stock par l’achat de 50 casiers de bière.
texts.en:
Mr. Koffi Mensah Edem Z., 27, is single and has no children. He was not able to stay at school for long. He got into commerce at a young age and began work in 2002. Events led him to open a drinks depot in a busy corner of his neighborhood. His business soon began to prosper.

He often finds himself out of certain items. Thus, he needs this, his first loan to add to his inventory by buying 50 cases of beer.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 50 cases of beer

loans.name: Salamata

texts.fr:
